newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Commission says will resist US pressure on grain tariffs.
newsitem.headline: Commission says will resist US pressure on grain tariffs.

text.p: The European Commission said on Wednesday it will not bow to pressure after the United States decided to pursue its complaint against the EU's grain tariff system at the World Trade Organistion.

U.S. officials said earlier in Geneva they were still pressing ahead with the case despite the withdrawal on Tuesday of a request to the WTO's Dispute Settlement Body (DSB) for the immediate creation of a panel to adjudicate whether the EU system violated the body's rules.
"It was just a technical matter," one U:S: source said of Tuesday's move. "We will be renewing the request in the near future."
A Commission spokesman said: "They might think it's a lever but it's not,"
European Commission and U.S. farm officials are locked in negotiations for a veterinary agreement and problems over imports of U.S. rice and malting barley.

Washington has complained that the EU's grain tariff system breaks WTO rules and that Brussels has delayed implementing agreed trade concessions to compensate for U.S. exporters' losses after Austria, Sweden and Finland joined the EU in 1995.
The Commission says it's working hard on import systems that would satisfy the U.S. and prevent fraud.
"We are fully committed to implementing the agreements but they are very complicated and take time," the spokesman said.
On Wednesday, the Commission proposed opening a 30,000 tonnes tariff quota for imports of U.S. malting barley in 1996 at half the full duty.
